\section{The way below relation}

We first define the notion of a directed family. This is actually
defined in the `Dcpo` module but I am redefining it here to avoid
importing the `Dcpo` module. There are also some things about that
definition that make it a bit inconvenient to work with. It might be
good idea to address this duplication at some point.

\begin{code}

is-directed : (P : Poset ùì§ ùì•) ‚Üí (S : Fam ùì¶ ‚à£ P ‚à£‚Çö) ‚Üí Œ© (ùì• ‚äî ùì¶)
is-directed P (I , s) =
   ‚à• I ‚à•Œ©
 ‚àß (‚±Ø i Íûâ I , ‚±Ø j Íûâ I , ∆é k Íûâ I , ((s i ‚â§ s k) ‚àß (s j ‚â§ s k)) holds)
  where open PosetNotation P using (_‚â§_)

\end{code}

\begin{code}

way-below : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí Œ© (ùì§ ‚äî ùì• ‚äî ùì¶ ‚Å∫)
way-below {ùì§ = ùì§} {ùì¶ = ùì¶} F U V =
 ‚±Ø S Íûâ Fam ùì¶ ‚ü® F ‚ü© , is-directed (poset-of F) S ‚áí
  V ‚â§ (‚ãÅ[ F ] S) ‚áí (∆é i Íûâ index S , (U ‚â§ S [ i ]) holds)
   where
    open PosetNotation (poset-of F) using (_‚â§_)

infix 5 way-below

syntax way-below F U V = U ‚â™[ F ] V

\end{code}

A compact open is one that is way below itself.

\begin{code}

is-compact-open : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí Œ© (ùì§ ‚äî ùì• ‚äî ùì¶ ‚Å∫)
is-compact-open F U = U ‚â™[ F ] U

\end{code}

A compact frame is simply a frame whose top element is finite.

\begin{code}

is-compact : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶ ‚Üí Œ© (ùì§ ‚äî ùì• ‚äî ùì¶ ‚Å∫)
is-compact F = is-compact-open F ùüè[ F ]

\end{code}

Compacts opens are always closed undery binary joins.

\begin{code}

compacts-are-closed-under-joins : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶)
                                ‚Üí (U V : ‚ü® F ‚ü©)
                                ‚Üí is-compact-open F U holds
                                ‚Üí is-compact-open F V holds
                                ‚Üí is-compact-open F (U ‚à®[ F ] V) holds
compacts-are-closed-under-joins F U V Œ∫‚ÇÅ Œ∫‚ÇÇ S dir@(_ , up) p =
 ‚à•‚à•-rec‚ÇÇ ‚àÉ-is-prop Œ≥ s‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ s‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤
  where
   open PosetNotation  (poset-of F) using (_‚â§_)
   open PosetReasoning (poset-of F)

\end{code}

We know that both `U` and `V` are covered by `S` by the assumption that `U ‚à® V`
is covered by `S`

\begin{code}

   q‚ÇÅ : (U ‚â§ (‚ãÅ[ F ] S)) holds
   q‚ÇÅ = U ‚â§‚ü® ‚à®[ F ]-upper‚ÇÅ U V ‚ü© U ‚à®[ F ] V ‚â§‚ü® p ‚ü© ‚ãÅ[ F ] S ‚ñ†

   q‚ÇÇ : (V ‚â§ (‚ãÅ[ F ] S)) holds
   q‚ÇÇ = V ‚â§‚ü® ‚à®[ F ]-upper‚ÇÇ U V ‚ü© U ‚à®[ F ] V ‚â§‚ü® p ‚ü© ‚ãÅ[ F ] S ‚ñ†

\end{code}

Therefore there must exist indices `i‚ÇÅ` and `i‚ÇÇ` such that `U ‚â§ S·µ¢‚ÇÅ` and `V ‚â§
S·µ¢‚ÇÇ`.

\begin{code}

   s‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ : ‚à• Œ£ i‚ÇÅ Íûâ index S , (U ‚â§ S [ i‚ÇÅ ]) holds ‚à•
   s‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ = Œ∫‚ÇÅ S dir q‚ÇÅ

   s‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ : ‚à• Œ£ i‚ÇÇ Íûâ index S , (V ‚â§ S [ i‚ÇÇ ]) holds ‚à•
   s‚ÇÇ‚Ä≤ = Œ∫‚ÇÇ S dir q‚ÇÇ

   Œ≥ : (Œ£ i‚ÇÅ Íûâ index S , (U ‚â§ S [ i‚ÇÅ ]) holds)
     ‚Üí (Œ£ i‚ÇÇ Íûâ index S , (V ‚â§ S [ i‚ÇÇ ]) holds)
     ‚Üí ‚àÉ i Íûâ index S , ((U ‚à®[ F ] V) ‚â§ S [ i ]) holds
   Œ≥ (i‚ÇÅ , s‚ÇÅ) (i‚ÇÇ , s‚ÇÇ) = ‚à•‚à•-rec ‚àÉ-is-prop Œ¥ (up i‚ÇÅ i‚ÇÇ)
    where
     Œ¥ : Œ£ i Íûâ index S , ((S [ i‚ÇÅ ] ‚â§ S [ i ]) ‚àß (S [ i‚ÇÇ ] ‚â§ S [ i ])) holds
       ‚Üí ‚àÉ i Íûâ index S , ((U ‚à®[ F ] V) ‚â§ S [ i ]) holds
     Œ¥ (i , r‚ÇÅ , r‚ÇÇ) = ‚à£ i , ‚à®[ F ]-least Œµ Œ∂ ‚à£
      where
       Œµ : (U ‚â§ S [ i ]) holds
       Œµ = U ‚â§‚ü® s‚ÇÅ ‚ü© S [ i‚ÇÅ ] ‚â§‚ü® r‚ÇÅ ‚ü© S [ i ] ‚ñ†

       Œ∂ : (V ‚â§ S [ i ]) holds
       Œ∂ = V ‚â§‚ü® s‚ÇÇ ‚ü© S [ i‚ÇÇ ] ‚â§‚ü® r‚ÇÇ ‚ü© S [ i ] ‚ñ†

\end{code}

\section{Well Inside}

`well-inside‚ÇÄ` is the type family expressing that a given open of a frame is
clopen.

\begin{code}

well-inside‚ÇÄ : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí ùì§ Ãá
well-inside‚ÇÄ F U V =
 Œ£ W Íûâ ‚ü® F ‚ü© , (U ‚àß[ F ] W Ôºù ùüé[ F ]) √ó (V ‚à®[ F ] W Ôºù ùüè[ F ])

infix 4 well-inside‚ÇÄ

syntax well-inside‚ÇÄ F U V = U ‚ãú‚ÇÄ[ F ] V

\end{code}

The well inside relation is not propositional in general, even though the ‚Äúhas
complement‚Äù predicate (i.e. is well inside itself) is propositional.

\begin{code}

  Œ≥‚ÇÇ : ùüé[ IF ] ‚ãú‚ÇÄ[ IF ] ùüè[ IF ]

        where
         abstract
          Œ≤ : ùüé[ IF ] ‚àß[ IF ] ùüè[ IF ] Ôºù ùüé[ IF ]

          Œ≥ : ùüè[ IF ] ‚à®[ IF ] ùüè[ IF ] Ôºù ùüè[ IF ]
          Œ≥ = ùüè-right-annihilator-for-‚à® IF ùüè[ IF ]

  Œ≥‚ÇÅ : ùüé[ IF ] ‚ãú‚ÇÄ[ IF ] ùüè[ IF ]
  Œ≥‚ÇÅ = ùüé[ IF ] , (Œ≤ , Œ≥)
        where
         abstract
          Œ≤ : ùüé[ IF ] ‚àß[ IF ] ùüé[ IF ] Ôºù ùüé[ IF ]
          Œ≤ = ùüé-right-annihilator-for-‚àß IF ùüé[ IF ]

  ùüé-is-not-ùüè p = Œ≥
   where
    Œ≥ : ‚ä• holds
    Œ≥ = transport _holds (ùüè[ IF ] Ôºù‚ü® p ‚Åª¬π ‚ü© ùüé[ IF ] Ôºù‚ü® ùüé-of-IF-is-‚ä• pe ‚ü© ‚ä• ‚àé) ‚ãÜ

  Œµ œà = ùüé-is-not-ùüè (pr‚ÇÅ (from-Œ£-Ôºù Œ¥))
   where
    Œ¥ : Œ≥‚ÇÅ Ôºù Œ≥‚ÇÇ
    Œ¥ = œà ùüé[ IF ] ùüè[ IF ] Œ≥‚ÇÅ Œ≥‚ÇÇ

\end{code}

Because well inside is not propositional, we have to truncate it to get a
relation.

\begin{code}

well-inside : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí Œ© ùì§

infix 4 well-inside

syntax well-inside F U V = U ‚ãú[ F ] V

\end{code}

\begin{code}

\begin{code}

An open _U_ in a frame _A_ is *clopen* iff it is well-inside itself.

\begin{code}


is-boolean-complement-of : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí Œ© ùì§
is-boolean-complement-of F U‚Ä≤ U =
 (U ‚àß[ F ] U‚Ä≤ Ôºù[ iss ]Ôºù ùüé[ F ]) ‚àß (U ‚à®[ F ] U‚Ä≤ Ôºù[ iss ]Ôºù ùüè[ F ])
  where
   iss = carrier-of-[ poset-of F ]-is-set

complementation-is-symmetric : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) (x y : ‚ü® F ‚ü©)
                             ‚Üí (is-boolean-complement-of F x y

 where
  ‚Ä† : x ‚àß[ F ] y Ôºù ùüé[ F ]
  ‚Ä† = x ‚àß[ F ] y Ôºù‚ü® ‚àß[ F ]-is-commutative x y ‚ü© y ‚àß[ F ] x Ôºù‚ü® œÜ ‚ü© ùüé[ F ] ‚àé

  ‚Ä° : x ‚à®[ F ] y Ôºù ùüè[ F ]
  ‚Ä° = x ‚à®[ F ] y Ôºù‚ü® ‚à®[ F ]-is-commutative x y ‚ü© y ‚à®[ F ] x Ôºù‚ü® œà ‚ü© ùüè[ F ] ‚àé

‚àß-complement : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶)

             ‚Üí is-boolean-complement-of F x x‚Ä≤ holds

  œÜ‚ÇÄ : x ‚äì x‚Ä≤ Ôºù ùüé[ F ]
  œÜ‚ÇÄ = x ‚äì x‚Ä≤ Ôºù‚ü® ‚àß[ F ]-is-commutative x x‚Ä≤ ‚ü© x‚Ä≤ ‚äì x Ôºù‚ü® pr‚ÇÅ œÜ ‚ü©  ùüé[ F ] ‚àé

  œà‚ÇÄ = y ‚äì y‚Ä≤ Ôºù‚ü® ‚àß[ F ]-is-commutative y y‚Ä≤ ‚ü© y‚Ä≤ ‚äì y  Ôºù‚ü® pr‚ÇÅ œà ‚ü© ùüé[ F ] ‚àé

  œÜ‚ÇÅ : x ‚à®[ F ] x‚Ä≤ Ôºù ùüè[ F ]
  œÜ‚ÇÅ = x  ‚à®[ F ] x‚Ä≤ Ôºù‚ü® ‚à®[ F ]-is-commutative x x‚Ä≤ ‚ü©
       x‚Ä≤ ‚à®[ F ] x  Ôºù‚ü® pr‚ÇÇ œÜ                      ‚ü©
       ùüè[ F ]       ‚àé

  Œ≤ : (x ‚àß[ F ] y) ‚àß[ F ] (x‚Ä≤ ‚à®[ F ] y‚Ä≤) Ôºù ùüé[ F ]
  Œ≤ = (x ‚äì y) ‚äì (x‚Ä≤ ‚à®[ F ] y‚Ä≤)                Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö† ‚ü©
      ((x ‚äì y) ‚äì x‚Ä≤) ‚à®[ F ] ((x ‚äì y) ‚äì y‚Ä≤)    Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö° ‚ü©
      ((y ‚äì x) ‚äì x‚Ä≤) ‚à®[ F ] ((x ‚äì y) ‚äì y‚Ä≤)    Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö¢ ‚ü©

      (x ‚äì y) ‚äì y‚Ä≤                            Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö¶ ‚ü©
      x ‚äì (y ‚äì y‚Ä≤)                            Ôºù‚ü® ‚Öß ‚ü©

      ùüé[ F ]                                  ‚àé
       where
        ‚Ö† = binary-distributivity F (x ‚äì y) x‚Ä≤ y‚Ä≤

        ‚Ö¶ = ‚àß[ F ]-is-associative x y y‚Ä≤ ‚Åª¬π
        ‚Öß = ap (Œª - ‚Üí x ‚äì -) œà‚ÇÄ
        ‚Ö® = ùüé-right-annihilator-for-‚àß F x


  Œ≥ : (x ‚äì y) ‚à®[ F ] (x‚Ä≤ ‚à®[ F ] y‚Ä≤) Ôºù ùüè[ F ]
  Œ≥ = (x ‚äì y) ‚à®[ F ] (x‚Ä≤ ‚à®[ F ] y‚Ä≤)                                Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö† ‚ü©

\section{Regularity}

\begin{code}

Even though this definition is a bit more convenient to work with, it simply

\section{Zero-dimensionality}

A locale L is said to be zero-dimensional iff it has a basis consisting of
clopen elements.

   ‚Ä†‚ÇÅ : (((x ‚à®[ F ] y) ‚àß[ F ] (x‚Ä≤ ‚àß[ F ] y‚Ä≤)) ‚â§[ poset-of F ] ùüé[ F ]) holds

Every zero-dimensional locale is regular.

\begin{code}

zero-dimensional-locales-are-regular : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶)
                                     ‚Üí is-zero-dimensional F holds
                                     ‚Üí is-regular F holds
zero-dimensional-locales-are-regular {ùì¶ = ùì¶} F =
 ‚à•‚à•-rec (holds-is-prop (is-regular F)) Œ≥
  where
   open Joins (Œª x y ‚Üí x ‚â§[ poset-of F ] y)

   Œ≥ : zero-dimensional·¥∞ F ‚Üí is-regular F holds
   Œ≥ (‚Ñ¨ , Œ≤ , Œæ) = ‚à£ ‚Ñ¨ , Œ¥ ‚à£
    where
     Œ¥ : Œ† U Íûâ ‚ü® F ‚ü© ,
          Œ£ J Íûâ Fam ùì¶ (index ‚Ñ¨) ,
             (U is-lub-of (fmap-syntax (_[_] ‚Ñ¨) J)) holds
           √ó (Œ† i Íûâ index J , (‚Ñ¨ [ J [ i ] ] ‚ãú[ F ] U) holds)
     Œ¥ U = ùí• , c , Œµ
      where
       ùí• = pr‚ÇÅ (pr‚ÇÅ Œ≤ U)

       c : (U is-lub-of ‚ÅÖ ‚Ñ¨ [ j ] ‚à£ j Œµ ùí• ‚ÅÜ) holds
       c = pr‚ÇÇ (pr‚ÇÅ Œ≤ U)

       Œµ : Œ† i Íûâ index ùí• , (‚Ñ¨ [ ùí• [ i ] ] ‚ãú[ F ] U) holds
       Œµ i = ‚Üë‚Üë-is-upwards-closed F ‚à£ Œæ (ùí• [ i ]) ‚à£ (pr‚ÇÅ c i)
        where
         Œ∑ : ((‚Ñ¨ [ ùí• [ i ] ]) ‚â§[ poset-of F ] (‚Ñ¨ [ ùí• [ i ] ])) holds
         Œ∑ = ‚â§-is-reflexive (poset-of F) (‚Ñ¨ [ ùí• [ i ] ])

compacts-are-clopen-in-zero-dimensional-locales : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶)
                                                ‚Üí is-zero-dimensional F holds
                                                ‚Üí (C : ‚ü® F ‚ü©)

                                                ‚Üí is-clopen F C holds

\end{code}

\section{Stone Locales}

A frame F is called Stone iff it is compact and zero-dimensional.

\begin{code}

is-stone : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) ‚Üí Œ© (ùì§ ‚äî ùì• ‚äî ùì¶ ‚Å∫)
is-stone F = is-compact F ‚àß is-zero-dimensional F

\end{code}

In a Stone locale, an open is a clopen iff it is compact.

\begin{code}

clopen-iff-compact-in-stone-frame : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶)
                                  ‚Üí is-stone F holds
                                  ‚Üí (U : ‚ü® F ‚ü©)
                                  ‚Üí (is-clopen F U holds)
                                  ‚Üî (is-compact-open F U holds)
clopen-iff-compact-in-stone-frame F (Œ∫ , Œ∂) U = Œ≤ , Œ≥
 where
  Œ≤ : (is-clopen F U ‚áí is-compact-open F U) holds
  Œ≤ = clopens-are-compact-in-compact-frames F Œ∫ U

  œÅ : is-regular F holds
  œÅ = zero-dimensional-locales-are-regular F Œ∂

  Œ≥ : (is-compact-open F U ‚áí is-clopen F U) holds
  Œ≥ = compacts-are-clopen-in-regular-frames F œÅ U

\end{code}

\section{Spectrality}

\begin{code}

    open Meets (Œª x y ‚Üí x ‚â§[ poset-of F ] y)

\end{code}

We now define the notion of spectrality. Note that closure under finite joins is
not an essential part of the definition. However, it can be assumed *without
loss of generality* and we assume it in the definition for the sake of
convenience.

\begin{code}

A continuous map `f : X ‚Üí Y` is called *perfect* if its right adjoint is
Scott-continuous.

\begin{code}

\end{code}

## Characterisation of continuity

Let `L` and `M` be two frames and let `h : | L | ‚Üí | M |` be a function.
Function `h` is said to satisfy the **continuity condition** if *for every `x :
L`, compact `b : M` with `b ‚â§ h(x)`, there is some compact `a : L` such that `a
‚â§ x` and `b ‚â§ h(a)`*.

\begin{code}

continuity-condition : (L : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) (M : Frame ùì§' ùì•' ùì¶)
                     ‚Üí (‚ü® L ‚ü© ‚Üí ‚ü® M ‚ü©) ‚Üí Œ© (ùì§ ‚äî ùì• ‚äî ùì¶ ‚Å∫ ‚äî ùì§' ‚äî ùì•')
continuity-condition L M h =
 ‚±Ø b Íûâ ‚ü® M ‚ü© , ‚±Ø x Íûâ ‚ü® L ‚ü© , is-compact-open M b ‚áí
  b ‚â§[ poset-of M ] h x ‚áí
   (∆é a Íûâ ‚ü® L ‚ü© ,
     ((is-compact-open L a ‚àß a ‚â§[ poset-of L ] x ‚àß b ‚â§[ poset-of M ] h a) holds))

\end{code}

Given frames `L` and `M`, with `M` spectral, any monotone function `h : ‚à£ L ‚à£ ‚Üí
‚à£ M ‚à£` satisfying the continuity condition is Scott-continuous.

\begin{code}

characterisation-of-continuity : (L : Frame ùì§  ùì•  ùì¶)

                               ‚Üí is-monotonic (poset-of L) (poset-of M) h holds

     where

         ‚ô£ (i , œà) = h a                    ‚â§‚ü® Œº (a , S [ i ]) œà               ‚ü©
                     h (S [ i ])            ‚â§‚ü® ‚ãÅ[ M ]-upper ‚ÅÖ h s ‚à£ s Œµ S ‚ÅÜ i  ‚ü©
                     ‚ãÅ[ M ] ‚ÅÖ h s ‚à£ s Œµ S ‚ÅÜ ‚ñ†

         ‚ô† : (h a ‚â§[ poset-of M ] (‚ãÅ[ M ] ‚ÅÖ h s ‚à£ s Œµ S ‚ÅÜ)) holds

              (holds-is-prop (h a ‚â§[ poset-of M ] (‚ãÅ[ M ] ‚ÅÖ h s ‚à£ s Œµ S ‚ÅÜ)))
              ‚ô£
              (Œ∫‚Çê S Œ¥ q)

\end{code}

We now prove the converse: given frames `L` and `M`, with `L` spectral, any
Scott-continuous function `h : ‚à£ L ‚à£ ‚Üí ‚à£ M ‚à£` satisfies the continuity condition.

\begin{code}

Let `F` be a spectral frame. Given `x, y, : F` and compact `a : F` with `a ‚â§ x ‚à®
y`, there exist compact `b, c : F` with `a ‚â§ b ‚à® c` such that `b ‚â§ x` and `c ‚â§
y`.

\begin{code}

compact-join-lemma : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶)

                   ‚Üí (x y a : ‚ü® F ‚ü©)

                   ‚Üí (a ‚â§[ poset-of F ] (x ‚à®[ F ] y)) holds

  Œò = ‚àÉ (K‚ÇÅ , K‚ÇÇ) Íûâ ‚ü® F ‚ü© √ó ‚ü® F ‚ü© ,

      √ó (K ‚â§[ poset-of F ] (K‚ÇÅ ‚à®[ F ] K‚ÇÇ)) holds

  Œ∂‚ÇÅ = ‚à®-is-scott-continuous‚Ä≤ F V

  œÜ‚ÇÅ : ‚àÉ K‚ÇÅ Íûâ ‚ü® F ‚ü© , (is-compact-open F K‚ÇÅ

  œÜ‚ÇÅ = characterisation-of-continuity-op F F œÉ c‚ÇÅ Œ∂‚ÇÅ K U Œ∫ œà

  ‚Ä† : Œ£ K‚ÇÅ Íûâ ‚ü® F ‚ü© , (is-compact-open F K‚ÇÅ
                    ‚àß (K‚ÇÅ ‚â§[ poset-of F ] U)
                    ‚àß K ‚â§[ poset-of F ] (K‚ÇÅ ‚à®[ F ] V)) holds
    ‚Üí Œò
  ‚Ä† (K‚ÇÅ , Œ∫‚ÇÅ , p‚ÇÅ , q‚ÇÅ) = ‚à•‚à•-rec ‚àÉ-is-prop ‚Ä° œÜ‚ÇÇ
   where
    c‚ÇÇ : ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü©

    Œ∂‚ÇÇ = ‚à®-is-scott-continuous F K‚ÇÅ

    ‚Ä° : (Œ£ K‚ÇÇ Íûâ ‚ü® F ‚ü© , (is-compact-open F K‚ÇÇ
                      ‚àß K‚ÇÇ ‚â§[ poset-of F ] V

      ‚Üí Œò
    ‚Ä° (K‚ÇÇ , Œ∫‚ÇÇ , p‚ÇÇ , q‚ÇÇ) = ‚à£ (K‚ÇÅ , K‚ÇÇ) , Œ∫‚ÇÅ , Œ∫‚ÇÇ , q‚ÇÇ , p‚ÇÅ , p‚ÇÇ ‚à£

    œÜ‚ÇÇ : ‚àÉ K‚ÇÇ Íûâ ‚ü® F ‚ü© , (is-compact-open F K‚ÇÇ

\begin{code}

\section{CNF Transformation for Spectrality}

Section added on 2023-08-17.

Given a basis closed under binary meets, the directification of that basis using
the `directify` function is also closed under binary meets. The reason is that
the meets of joins can be turned into joins of meets. In this section, we prove
this fact.

To define CNF transformation, we need the following function
`conjunct-with-list` which takes some `x` and some list `y‚ÇÅ , ‚Ä¶ , y‚Çô` and
computes `(x ‚àß y‚ÇÅ) , ‚Ä¶ , (x ‚àß y‚Çô)`.

\begin{code}

conjunct-with-list : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶)
                   ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí List ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí List ‚ü® F ‚ü©
conjunct-with-list F x = map (Œª - ‚Üí x ‚àß[ F ] -)

cnf-transform : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶)
              ‚Üí List ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí List ‚ü® F ‚ü© ‚Üí ‚ü® F ‚ü©
cnf-transform F []       ys = ùüé[ F ]
cnf-transform F (x ‚à∑ xs) ys =
 (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] conjunct-with-list F x ys) ‚à®[ F ] cnf-transform F xs ys

\end{code}

Given some `x : ‚ü® F ‚ü©` and a list `(y‚ÇÅ , ‚Ä¶ , y‚Çô) : List ‚ü® F ‚ü©`,
`x ‚àß (y‚ÇÅ ‚à® ‚Ä¶ ‚à® y‚Çô) Ôºù (x ‚àß y‚ÇÅ) ‚à® ‚Ä¶ ‚à® (x ‚àß y‚Çô)`, which is of course just an
instance of the distributivity law. We prove this fact next.

\begin{code}

distributivity-list : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) (x : ‚ü® F ‚ü©) (ys : List ‚ü® F ‚ü©)
                    ‚Üí x ‚àß[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys) Ôºù ‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] (conjunct-with-list F x ys)
distributivity-list F x []       = ùüé-right-annihilator-for-‚àß F x
distributivity-list F x (y ‚à∑ ys) =
 x ‚àß[ F ] (y ‚à®[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys))                         Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö†    ‚ü©
 (x ‚àß[ F ] y) ‚à®[ F ] (x ‚àß[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys))              Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö°    ‚ü©
 (x ‚àß[ F ] y) ‚à®[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] conjunct-with-list F x ys)  Ôºù‚ü® refl ‚ü©
 ‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] (conjunct-with-list F x (y ‚à∑ ys))                ‚àé
  where
   ‚Ö† = binary-distributivity F x y (join-list F ys)
   ‚Ö° = ap (Œª - ‚Üí (x ‚àß[ F ] y) ‚à®[ F ] -) (distributivity-list F x ys)

\end{code}

With `distributivity-list` in hand, we are ready to prove the correctness of the
CNF transformation procedure.

\begin{code}

cnf-transform-correct : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) (xs ys : List ‚ü® F ‚ü©)
                      ‚Üí (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] xs) ‚àß[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys) Ôºù cnf-transform F xs ys
cnf-transform-correct F []       ys = ùüé-left-annihilator-for-‚àß F ((‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys))
cnf-transform-correct F (x ‚à∑ xs) ys =
 (x ‚à®[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] xs)) ‚àß[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys)                       Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö†    ‚ü©
 (x ‚àß[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys)) ‚à®[ F ] ((‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] xs) ‚àß[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys)) Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö°    ‚ü©
 (x ‚àß[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys)) ‚à®[ F ] cnf-transform F xs ys              Ôºù‚ü® ‚Ö¢    ‚ü©
 (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] conjunct-with-list F x ys) ‚à®[ F ] cnf-transform F xs ys  Ôºù‚ü® refl ‚ü©
 cnf-transform F (x ‚à∑ xs) ys                                       ‚àé
  where
   ‚Ö† = binary-distributivity-right F
   ‚Ö° = ap
        (Œª - ‚Üí (x ‚àß[ F ] (‚ãÅ‚Çó[ F ] ys)) ‚à®[ F ] -)
        (cnf-transform-correct F xs ys)
   ‚Ö¢ = ap (Œª - ‚Üí - ‚à®[ F ] cnf-transform F xs ys) (distributivity-list F x ys)

\end{code}

We now start proving, making use of `cnf-transform-correct`, that the CNF
transformation of two basic opens is itself basic.

We first prove the analogous fact that the `conjunct-with-list` function:

\begin{code}

conjunct-with-list-is-basic : (F : Frame ùì§ ùì• ùì¶) (‚Ñ¨ : Fam ùì¶ ‚ü® F ‚ü©)
                            ‚Üí (Œ≤ : is-basis-for F ‚Ñ¨)
                            ‚Üí closed-under-binary-meets F ‚Ñ¨ holds
                            ‚Üí let
